Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Greenhouse gas balance of urban temperate wetlands

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to measure Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from wetlands and quantify the effects of weather, vegetation structure, and water level dynamics on components of the GHG budget of the wetland systems. To do this a combination of experimental and modeling tasks will be employed. Two distinct urban temperate wetland ecosystems, one in Ohio, a freshwater wetland, and one in New Jersey, a tidal salt marsh, will be studied. Methods combine direct measurements of CO2 and CH4 in the air over the two wetland systems, measurements of CH4 emissions in chambers, and measurements of wetland vegetation structure and ecophysiology in the context of an existing biosphere-atmosphere model. As the two wetlands to be investigated have been constructed or restored, all aspects of ecological engineering will be assessed for their effects on GHG emissions. The data collected in the wetlands will be used to parameterize the GHG emission module in the ecosystem model. This can be used as a planning tool to predict GHG budgets in different climates, wetland designs, and management practices. In addition to two Ph.D. candidates, two undergraduate students participating in the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) will be trained in climate change science through this project.

Bruce K. Hamilton

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to measure and evaluate carbon dioxide and methane fluxes in a restored urban tidal marsh in the New Jersey Meadowlands and a constructed freshwater wetland in Columbus, Ohio, which is still ongoing. While carbon dioxide fluxes reflected uptake of the respective wetlands and thus carbon sequestration, methane was emitted and thus added to the greenhouse gas burden in the atmosphere. Both, carbon dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4), exhibited seasonal patterns, whereby higher uptake of CO2 and higher emission of CH4 were observed in the summer compared to lower uptake and emissions in the winter. The seasonal differences were driven by net radiation and temperature. In addition, the fluxes at the tidal brackish wetlands were also affected by tidal inundation cycles. Strong coupling of carbon uptake and methane emissions were observed as plant carbon serves as substrate for methane production. Methane emissions are furthermore influenced by the water conductivity and plant species. There was a significant difference in CH4 emission between marshes vegetated by different species even though there were no differences in aboveground biomass. Albeit, biomass has been shown to relate to methane production in earlier studies. Invasive Phragmites australis emitted more CH4 than native Spartina patens, thus it is likely that ongoing invasion by P. australis in a S. patens marsh would increase CH4 emission. The effect of tides on CH4 fluxes has been found to differ between vegetated and non-vegetated areas, which should be due to different transport processes present between the two marsh zones. There was a weak relationship between vapor pressure deficit (VPD) and CH4 flux in the vegetated area, suggesting stomatal control of CH4 flux from vegetated areas. Analysis of d13C-CH4 indicated similar substrate use and methane production processes in the two different microsites in the restored tidal urban wetland. Most of the belowground biomass is close to the soil surface, suggesting that most of the root effect on production, consumption and transport of CH4 takes place near the soil surface. The NJ Meadowlands are a significant CH4 source, but CH4 production and release seems to be only weakly correlated with environmental drivers, showing strongest correlation with CO2 fluxes.

The global warming potential for methane at the tidal marsh was 45 or 35 (units?), depending on which model was used in 2012. However, the marsh’s carbon dioxide net exchange (i.e. uptake) of approximately 950 g C m-2 yr-1 in 2012 more than compensated for the methane emitted, signaling these wetlands to be valuable carbon storage ecosystems. In addition, hurricane Sandy hit the research sites in the New Jersey Meadowlands in October 2012. Albeit, CH4 emission increased at the restored site from 2012 to 2013, potentially signaling an effect of hurricane Sandy, however at an accompanying study in a natural wetland site, the CH4 fluxes decreased from 2012 to 2013. Thus, overall, neither carbon dioxide nor methane fluxes were significantly affected, demonstrating a strong resiliency of these ecosystems to external perturbations.
